original_data.question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health examination. She feels well but asks for advice about smoking cessation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. She has tried to quit several times without success. During the previous attempts, she has been extremely nervous and also gained weight. She has also tried nicotine lozenges but stopped taking them because of severe headaches and insomnia. She has bulimia nervosa. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

model_response:
The patient has failed in her previous attempts to stop smoking, and her current problem is weight gain during attempts to stop smoking. These facts suggest that she may have a nicotine use disorder. The most appropriate next step in management is to use varenicline, which is a partial agonist at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. This drug is effective in smoking cessation and reduces the urge to smoke. It also may reduce the risk of relapse in individuals who have been abstinent for at least 1 week. Varenicline is a first-line agent for smoking cessation. The most common side effects are headache, nausea, and insomnia. The use of varenicline in individuals with bulimia nervosa has not been reported. However, the drug should not be used in individuals with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, or serious psychological distress. The other choices are not appropriate for this patient. Diazepam is a benzodiazepine that is not indicated for smoking cessation. The nicotine patch is a first-line agent for smoking cessation, but it has not been shown to reduce weight gain during smoking cessation. Motivational interviewing is a counseling technique that is also a first-line agent for smoking cessation. It is not indicated for the treatment of nicotine use disorder.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
An unvarying or habitual method or procedure.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Emotional sensations.
Discontinuing the habit of SMOKING.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
An event that accomplishes its intended purpose.
The successful attempt to kill oneself.
An uneasy psychological state; the anxious feeling you have when you have the jitters.
Gain; to increase or the amount of increase.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.

A lozenge preparation containing the alkaloid nicotine with nicotine replacement activity. Upon administration of the lozenge, nicotine is released and, although nicotine binds to nicotinic cholinergic receptors at the autonomic ganglia, adrenal medulla and at neuromuscular junctions as well, the binding of nicotine to the receptors in the central nervous system (CNS) appears to be responsible for the addictive nature of nicotine. Binding to CNS nicotinic acetylcholine receptors causes the release of the neurotransmitter dopamine which appears to be responsible for the addiction of nicotine. Administration of nicotine may prevent nicotine craving and may help with the withdrawal symptoms associated with smoking cessation.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
A sleep disorder characterized by difficulty in falling asleep and/or remaining asleep.
Eating an excess amount of food in a short period of time, as seen in the disorder of BULIMIA NERVOSA. It is caused by an abnormal craving for food, or insatiable hunger also known as "ox hunger".
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Assessment of sensory and motor responses and reflexes that is used to determine impairment of the nervous system.
Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
